channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Families Refusing to Return, ‘Naked’ Officials Are Demoted
item.description: The series of demotions represents a new phase in the Communist Party’s campaign against “naked officials,” those who have sent their families to live overseas.
item.dc:creator: By JESS YU
item.media:description: A protest outside a courthouse in Langfang, China, where a former senior official, Liu Tienan, was sentenced to life in prison for bribery this month. China's anticorruption initiatives have wide public backing.

item.title: U.S. Frees Last of the ‘Cuban Five,’ Part of a 1990s Spy Ring
item.description: Three members of the Cuban Five — part of a spy ring that infiltrated exile groups in Florida in the 1990s — were released from prison as part of the sudden diplomatic thaw in relations.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: A billboard in Havana with Fidel Castro and the Cuban Five, left, spies who infiltrated exile groups in South Florida and who were also freed on Wednesday.

item.title: Journey to Reconciliation Visited Worlds of Presidents, Popes and Spies
item.description: The deal that restored full diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba ultimately rested with a spy swap.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama speaking with Cuba’s president, Raúl Castro, on Tuesday. On Wednesday, Mr. Obama ordered the restoration of full diplomatic relations.

item.title: 8 Children Killed in Home in Northern Australia
item.description: Eight dead children and a woman suffering from stab wounds were found inside a home, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A ‘Brave’ Move by Obama Removes a Wedge in Relations With Latin America
item.description: Leaders who have consistently lambasted the United States and President Obama abruptly changed course, praising the policy shift on Cuba.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Liberia Will Proceed With Senate Vote Delayed by Ebola
item.description: An election repeatedly delayed because of the epidemic and other challenges will be held on Saturday, but critics worry whether voting will fair and safe.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIR MacDOUGALL

item.title: News Analysis: A Diplomatic Triumph in Cuba Comes With a Challenge in North Korea
item.description: Cuba and North Korea are posing opposite challenges for the Obama administration — with Havana experimenting with integration, and Pyongyang brandishing a new weapon.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, center, at a ceremony Wednesday for the third anniversary of his father’s death.

item.title: The Revolution Fidel Castro Began Evolves Under His Brother
item.description: Fidel Castro, a venerable figure to generations of Cubans, is fading into history as his more pragmatic brother, Raúl, reshapes the nation.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: Students with a portrait of Fidel Castro at a march in Havana in September for spies who were imprisoned. Castro has not appeared in public for months.

item.title: Obama Intends to Lift Several Restrictions Against Cuba on His Own
item.description: Administration officials said travel and commerce restrictions could be lifted as early as next month.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama at the White House’s Hanukkah party. Administration officials said travel and commerce restrictions against Cuba could be lifted next month.

item.title: Crucial Spy in Cuba Paid a Heavy Cold War Price
item.description: Rolando Sarraff Trujillo, who was released Wednesday from a Cuban prison where he had been held since 1995, provided information on codes used by Cuban spies.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: Rolando Sarraff Trujillo, in a photo released by his family.

item.title: Listening Post: How Obama’s Undercover Statecraft Secured Three Major Accords
item.description: Small negotiating teams assembled by the administration slipped secretly away to bargaining tables at locations around the world to do the delicate work of diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Islamist Militants in Nigeria Kidnap 185 in a Deadly Attack on a Village
item.description: Boko Haram, the extremist group that operates widely in the volatile northeastern part of the country, is suspected of being responsible.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: South Koreans Back Japan’s Peace Constitution as Nobel Prize-Worthy
item.description: Prominent South Koreans started an effort on Thursday backing Japanese supporters of a constitutional provision that renounces war.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Businesses Scout Opportunities in Cuba
item.description: American companies were quick to start plans to bring products and services to a market they have not been in for the better part of 50 years — if ever.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE CRESWELL
item.media:description: American hotel companies hope to profit from an increase in tourism to Cuba. If travel restrictions are fully lifted, the annual number of visitors to Cuba could jump by a million, to 4 million, experts say.

item.title: Putin Cites Claim About U.S. Designs on Siberia Traced to Russian Mind Readers
item.description: Seeking to justify his foreign policy as essentially defensive, Russia’s president cited apocryphal remarks wrongly attributed to Madeleine Albright.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Malacca Journal: Celebrating the Legacy of a Chinese Explorer
item.description: A Malaysian town is commemorating the contributions of Zheng He, a Chinese seafarer who spread his country’s culture and architecture here in the 15th century.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Rahman Roslan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watching a video about the seafarer Zheng He, known as Cheng Ho in Malaysia, at a museum about his life in Malacca.

item.title: Cuba’s Fans in Canada Anxiously Picture an Island Awash in Americans
item.description: Many Canadians were lamenting that the thaw between Havana and Washington meant Cuba might soon cease to be an oasis with hardly an American in sight.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Foreign tourists at the Havana Cathedral last year. Canadians, in particular, worry that huge influx of American tourists will change Cuba for the worse.

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: ISIS Fighters Claim 2 Killings
item.description: Tunisian fighters with the Islamic State group have claimed responsibility in a video for the assassinations of two left-wing politicians.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: World Briefing: Obesity May Be a Disability, European Court Says
item.description: Obesity can be a disability, the European Court of Justice ruled Thursday, a decision that could have widespread consequences across the 28-nation European Union for the way in which employers deal with severely overweight employees.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Deadly Strife
item.description: Clashes between Muslim and Christian fighters have left at least 28 people dead, wounded dozens and sent civilians fleeing for safety, a Red Cross official said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
